title: What will be the U.S. civilian unemployment rate (U3) for October 2020?
preds: With the unemployment rate hovering between 6% and 10%  for the past three weeks this seems to have reached a base level. Considering the looming election and no further federal aid in sight there is not likely to be any significant decreases in the level of unemployment. Conversely, if cases continue to worsen across the US there could be a slow down of hiring and the following increase in unemployment.

Rate at the end of September was 7.9%, and so it looks like the trend is leveling out rather than continuing its drastic drop from before. To make a final jump another 1.9% down to below 6% is very unlikely, so I'm moving my forecast to a more reasonable estimate.

Since reaching the peak in March 2020 of 14.7%, the US unemployment rate has been steadily declining to the most recent value of 7.9% in September ->
https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000 Based on the unemployment rate change per month since March 2020, I believe the likelihood that the October 2020 US unemployment rate will be in the range of 6 -10% to be highly likely (approx. 90%). 6 - 10% = 90%
10.1 - 13.9% = 10%

Job creation slowing over the last several weeks.
Unexpected increase in first time unemployment claims this week.
Below 6% is out of the question in my opinion. Doubtful that the rate will jump from 7.9% to more than 10%.
I'm pretty certain about this.  I'm puzzled why some forecasts more than 10.0%  Why would it turn around and start rising when it's been dropping each month since March.
Pretty simple extrapolation from the data here: https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.t15.htm
You can't make anything idiot proof because idiots are so ingenious.
Updating for unemployment being 7.9% in Sept.

The unemployment rate for September was 7.9 [1]. Forecasts.com has 7.2 for October [2]. All in on the 2nd bucket. [1] https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/02/economy/september-2020-jobs-report-election/index.html
[2] https://www.forecasts.org/unemploy.htm
Rate seems to being holding steady and not dropping like it was earlier.
Very unlikely it jumps much in either direction in one month. Useful graphic on temporary vs permanent unemployed: https://twitter.com/ModeledBehavior/status/1313147757130117120

Capitulation. This one will sting me a little... Hatip to @juancambeiro and @ThWedler  I've learned the difference in the "feeling" between U3 and U6 Employment. Kinda wondering what the relevance of U3 actually is. My feel is that its for seriously macro-wonks. The "on the ground" reality out there is that far more than 6-10% of Americans are "functionally" unemployed.

After yesterday's payrolls, it has become virtually certain for the October figure to be within 6.0%-10.0%, with current at 7.9%. Just one month to go, and a lot of potential risk factors like Covid and elections already anticipated by employers. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/unemployment-rate The US unemployment rate declined to 7.9 percent in September 2020 from 8.4 percent in the previous month and below market expectations of 8.2 percent, as fewer people were looking for jobs. The labor force dropped by 0.7 million to 160.1 million, with the number of unemployed persons falling by 1.0 million to 12.6 million and employment rising by just 0.3 million to 147.5 million.

"Total nonfarm payroll employment rose by 661,000 in September, and the unemployment
rate declined to 7.9 percent [from 8.4%] ... had misclassified workers been included, the overall September unemployment rate would have been 0.4 percentage point higher than reported." https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.nr0.htm The unemployment rate only declined by 0.5% from August to September. Given an overall slowdown in the recovery, it's probably safer to assume that the unemployment rate won't decline more than another 0.5% from September to October (even if it did, this would put the October unemployment rate at 7.4% — very comfortably within the 6.0-10.0% bucket). I also don't think the unemployment rate will rise (again, even if it did it would still fall comfortably in the 6.0-10.0% bucket).
updating - very low odds of a more than 2% swing next month given recent trajectory

Jobless claims today again way below 1M and better than expected. Would take quite a dramatic change of direction over the next few weeks to fall outside the 6-10% bin. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/jobless-claims
The number of Americans filling for unemployment benefits rose by 837 thousand in the week ended September 26th, compared to an upwardly revised 873 thousand in the previous period and slightly below market expectations of 850 thousand. It was the fifth consecutive week with claims stuck at the 800 thousand level, pointing to a slowdown in the labor market recovery.

Last updated figure was 8.4%, which has come down from the peak in March 2020 at 14.7%. Between 2010 and 2020 it dropped from 9.8% to 3.5%. The unemployment rate has been dropping steadily from 14.7% every month, and so will likely not rise above 8.4% again. The question is whether it will drop below 6.0% in September and October.  Based on the linear trend line from 14.7% in March to X% in October (drop of 1.58%/month), its expected that the rate would be 5.25%. Will it really follow a linear trend line? I think its likely that it will slow down as there will be friction in returning to work with many businesses permanently closed, and covid-19 continuing to force people to not travel and stay at home. The economy is doing well, and many businesses seem to be going back to work, but there is still an entire section of the retail and hospitality world that requires consumer spending and in-person work, making it less likely that it will drop below 6%.
Assumes a new CARES happens in October.
August 8.4%  So far through September, holding.
past 11 years of annual unemployment is 6.5%. 14.7	13.3	11.1	10.2	8.4 - unemployment since August 2020. It is going down by 1-2 percent monthly. This rate likely will sustain.
UE Rate is currently 8.4%, initial claims stalling likely indicating the UE rate staying near where it is.
Assuming a new CARES comes into effect in October, the bleeding may stop.

Weekly data just in: "The number of Americans filling for unemployment benefits rose by 870 thousand in the week ended September 19th, the fourth consecutive week with claims below 1 million but above market expectations of 840 thousand."  https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/jobless-claims Worse than expected, but... still in the ballpark that most recently corresponds with a 8% rather than a 10% handle on the unemployment rate. Firming up that bin with not much time / data releases left.

https://www.forecasts.org/unemploy.htm
https://www.forecasts.org/service/about.htm
If they are accurate for September I will stick with this more extreme forecast.
Early forecast, assuming unemployment continues to decrease and firms start to hire again soon. I will update in a few weeks.
I'll follow @erikbays into the woods. Maybe the smoke will clear tomorrow and we'll all be able to see the sun again.

Wall Street Journal: "U.S. Unemployment Claims Held Steady at 860,000 Last Week".  Explanation why I think less than 6% is possible:  Since start of pandemic when unemployment shot up the drop each month has been fairly large and if you simply extrapolate out to October, it goes below 6%.  Of course you don't expect the drop to continue at same rate. I'm not any more confident though since recent not good economic news and we are still in pandemic.

According to a recent FiveThirtyEight/IGM Economic Survey [1, 2], the consensus forecast of 28 quantitative macroeconomic economists is that the U3 unemployment rate for September 2020 will be 8.0% (80% CI: 7.6%, 8.5%). The next consensus forecast is for December 2020, for which the median point estimate is 7.6% (80% CI: 6.5%, 8.5%). Given that the consensus forecast for December is slightly more optimistic than for September, we can probably expect continued improvement from the September unemployment rate (median point estimate of 8.0%) to the October unemployment rate (which this question asks about). Given this, and also given that the 90th percentile for the consensus forecast for September is 8.5%, I think we can safely rule out an October unemployment rate of 10.0% or greater — thus eliminating bins 3, 4, 5, 6. Moreover, it also seems very unlikely that the October unemployment rate will be lower than 6.0% given that the 10th percentile of the consensus forecast for December 2020 is only 6.5%. So I think we can also rule out an unemployment rate of less than 6.0% — thus eliminating bin 1. Only bin 2 is left, and the October unemployment rate is likely to be safely somewhere in the middle of the 6.0-10.0% range rather than toward one of the ends of this range. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/economists-dont-think-the-lower-unemployment-rate-signals-a-clear-recovery/
[2] http://www.igmchicago.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Results-Round-08.pdf
August figure was 8.4pc.  Less likely to hit bins 4 5 or 6.

How are things going in your neighborhood? Following the admonition of @Dillyweed I'm moving 5 pts to bucket 3.
As more jobs may be impacted by structural changes in the economy that could become permanent.
Fell asleep on the wheel on this one.  Going hard on bin 2 for now, as I've been very very heavy on bin 3 most of forecast.
Adjusting my number closer to the crowd and still may be over-confident.

8.4% now + 0.4% for end of census + 0.2% for airline layoffs = 9.0% as my expectation. Maybe an extra +/-0.5% for randomness in the numbers. If the economy swings hard vs current trend then that will go up. Maybe 90/10 is too aggressive. Bump to 85/15.
8.4% but caveats are some lowering was census workers and covid probably going up in fall might lead to pull back. If death rate snd hospitalizations do not rise then all in on bin 2.

Unemployment going down and was at 8.4 for August.[1] My guess is that people simply stops reporting they are unemployed and looking for work and not that the underlying problems is solved. With that said it is the numbers from BLS we are looking at. 
I'm drastically reducing the number downward since the unemployment numbers has been trending down since April. Data might be a misleading with government hiring a lot of temporary census workers [2] and I have hard time to predict what the consequences of the absence of a stimulus package from the government will cause. Will certainly look closely at the numbers for September. <6: 1
6-10: +43
10-14: -26
14-18: -18
18-22: 0
>22: 0 1. https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000
2. https://www.bbc.com/news/business-54029361

WHile the real unemployment may be higher, between April (start of effects of the pandemic) and August, unemployment has been between 14.7% & 8.4%.  In the last 4 months, the average decrease per month has been 13%.  At a 13% decrease in Sep/Oct, we can expect Oct to be 6%.  if we see August's trend to continue, the lowest it would be is 4%.
Adjusting down after new unemployment numbers
It will go back up when temp census jobs disappear at the end of next month.
Updating based on August number of 8.4%.

Some interesting tidbits about the current U.S. unemployment situation — — "U.S. unemployment dropped sharply in August from 10.2% to a still-high 8.4%, with about half the 22 million jobs lost to the coronavirus outbreak recovered so far ... The drop in unemployment was sharper than most economists expected and was attributed mainly to businesses recalling workers who had been temporarily laid off." [1]
— "The data collection error that had marred past jobs reports continues to have some effect on the numbers. The Bureau of Labor Statistics said that the unemployment rate for August could be as much as seven-tenths of a percentage point higher because of the data collection mistake." [2]
— "Nearly a fifth of the job gains reported by the Labor Department on Friday were from the government’s temporary hiring for the 2020 Census." [3] [1] https://apnews.com/3b986be61c960c484a274837c5791909
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/09/04/economy-adds-14-million-jobs-august-unemployment-rate-fell-below-10-percent-first-time-since-pandemic-took-hold/
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy/u-s-job-growth-seen-slowing-in-august-unemployment-rate-falling-below-10-idUSKBN25V0FO
August showed 8.4%, assuming more job losses coming in Oct due to Congressional inaction and business models held hostage to Covid-19 assume we'll rise to 10% level.

I see that many forecasters have the tendency to give extra weight to bin we currently are in instead of bin the trend is pointing towards.
This question is classic example to this behavior.

Finally some good news from the main street.....
[1] https://finance.yahoo.com/news/august-jobs-report-labor-department-coronavirus-pandemic-unemployment-200735185.html
Dropped a bit more than I was expecting this month. I still don't think it'll go under 6 in October but the odds are a bit higher now. Odds of over 10 seem very small now.

Despite weaker Payrolls, the unemployment rate for August tanked. Reassessing.
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/unemployment-rate
The US unemployment rate fell to 8.4 percent in August of 2020 from 10.2 percent in the previous month and below market expectations of 9.8 percent, as many businesses continued to reopen and rehire employees following coronavirus lockdowns. The number of unemployed persons dropped by 2.8 million to 13.6 million.

Out this morning: United States ADP Employment Change. "Private businesses in the US hired just 428K workers in August of 2020, way below market expectations of a 950K rise."
Not the most salient of labor reports, but an important data point prior to Friday's payrolls.
Waiting for August data, but the trend is toward below 10%.
Structural Unemployment is permanent loss of jobs due to changes in the economy.
Above 10% now but trend looks like will be below in October.

Important data in the week ahead: ADP Employment on Wednesday, Initial Jobless Claims on Thursday and Non-Farm Payrolls on Friday (with importance increasing as the week goes on). In the meantime, the economic data has arguably been a lot better than expected (except maybe Chicago PMI) and I am just narrowing in on the 10-14% bin.
Assuming structural unemployment changes will become evident by October. These are jobs that are not likely to come back even with an economic recovery.
ongoing issues, but trend has been lower and nearing 10% in August with further potential for improvement

The recent airline announcements, and state and local government staff reductions to come will have an impact on employment. In general these are good middle income jobs that will be lost for a long time. Local schools and universities are also likely to add to the pain. Covid-19 has crippled many business models with no short term fix.
When they are released next week, expecting the August numbers to come below 10%
Latest figures confirm a gradual decline in UI claims (new and existing).
Current rate is 10.2 but I expect that number to rise.

I think the rapid drop in unemployment over the last couple months will slow down. For one, many of those were likely temporary unemployments that have been returning to their jobs. The temporarily unemployed will likely have mostly returned to work by then, leaving more of a "true" unemployment number, which will still be elevated due to businesses failing during coronavirus. The other factor is that the $600 unemployment benefit has not yet been extended, and without that people who previously wanted to avoid coronavirus risk may attempt to find work. The July number was 10.2% unemployment, I think that will continue to drop but at a slower pace, leaving it pretty solidly in the 6 to 10 percent range. My ballpark number is maybe 8%-8.5% in October. I give over 10% unemployment a 9% chance because it's possible cases worsen during the winter leading to more shutdowns and unemployment increases, and I think congress will probably pass more unemployment benefits when it returns to session in September.
Recent new filings and the expectation of further staff reductions in education and government as public entities can no longer afford all their staff due to drastically reduced tax revenue.
More layoffs of government workers. More pull back in some areas due to increase in cases. Going with crowd on this one.

Torn. Current initial claims are consistent with a 9-handle, but on the other hand July is probably "as good as it gets". Need to keep watching weekly labor stats closely, and where possible early activity indicators like IHS Markit US Sector PMI (next one early September), Cass trucking etc.
https://www.bbc.com/news/business-53770694
Weekly claims continue to trend downward dropping ~15% since last week. -3% to 10-14, +3% to 6-10.

Need time to think about it [1,2]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1105479
[2] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-economists-fear-will-happen-without-more-unemployment-aid/
US Unemployment rate will drop below 10% in February 2021.

Using the data supplied FiveThiryEight for Dec 2020 I swagged the probabilities above. Your mileage may vary.
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-economists-fear-will-happen-without-more-unemployment-aid/

My original estimates put the rate very high. Closer to the original 18% or more, level.  I had calculated job losses so I knew it was possible. I think I'm not totally clear on how/when job losses translate to unemployment (you have to be searching, you have to have a certain kind of employment before, etc) and it meant my estimates were off. This time, I'm more just looking at the magnitude of shock we previously had at start of Covid, saw that it sent us to only the 10% range, and therefore lowered my estimates. I will say, all signs are suggesting we're entering a new "great recession" but that peaked at 10%.

This free Bloomberg article on Yahoo finance from Saturday is not a bad summary of the dynamics likely to shape US unemployment in the next three months. In summary:
- "Easy gains" in May, June, July not to be repeated
- Unemployment benefits ran out
- Industries most affected by pandemic are laying off again as vaccine still far away and Covid worsened in many states
Nothing ground-breaking but good enough for confirming/tightening the curve.
https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/employment-u-increased-more-forecast-124031058.html
10.2 % now but the economy could easily get worse with the decrease in government funding to people. All those government jobs lost also has a drag on the general economy.

The unemployment rate for July was about 10%, but many feel this undercounts [2]. With any sort of releif package under question [4], more than half of Americans fear losing their job [3]. Forecasts.com is putting the number for October at 8.2% [1] last updated Aug 7th.  The Forecasts.com number seems low to me based on the feeling in the country, particular displayed in [3], and the uncertainty of any relief package moving forward, and the possibility of either further outbreaks. I am going to take it away from the 4th bucket, though, as it looks like the US will be tripping along at or around 10% for the foreseeable future. [1] https://www.forecasts.org/unemploy.htm
[2] https://www.forbes.com/sites/eriksherman/2020/08/07/whats-the-real-unemployment-rate-102-or-188/#5aaec50c1c2a

[4] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/07/coronavirus-stimulus-updates-relief-bill-stalls-trump-mulls-executive-order.html
Sitting on the bubble. Lots of jobs still to be lost as temporary support expires this fall.
In July the unemployment rate was 10.2%, down from 11.1% in June. https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf

Unemployment went down to 11.1 in June as @glenndupaul's link showed. Lower than surveyed economists predicted. While there still is huge uncertainty the initial shock seem to be over. I'm updating my numbers to be close to the current unemployment numbers.

The US continues to lead the world in new cases daily, this does not bode well for employment because it curtails spending. Without swift action by Congress to provide funds for those impacted economic contraction may only accelerate. Therefore I am increasing the probability in the fourth bucket. Leadership and actions matter - we have neither.

Congressional dilly dallying leading to a failure to extend the $600 unemployment insurance benefit makes it significantly more likely that unemployment will begin rising as we approach October given ordinary americans will have less disposable income.
The BLS weekly UI claims show the like advanced unemployment rate moved up .5% to 11.6% from 11.1% on a weekly basis. -5% to 6-10, +4% to 10-14, +1% to 14-18. https://www.dol.gov/ui/data.pdf

It is projected to be in the 11-15% range by a number of analysts. Congressional Budget Office: The unemployment rate is projected to average 15 percent during the second and third quarters of 2020, up from less than 4 percent in the first quarter.

2020	3.6	3.5	4.4	14.7	13.3	11.1	July?  Aug?  Sept? Oct?
It would appear structural changes occur in Q3 replacing temporary changes occuring in Q2.
updating to remove tails as event approaches

Considering the current rate of 11.1 %, increasing spread of SARS-CoV2, and more and more places opting to keep schools closed in the fall, I believe the unemployment rate will increase again.  Whether due to areas having to shut back down due to out of control viral spread, business choosing to close their doors for good, losing a job due to lack of childcare and related time taken off, or choosing to leave a job as the cost of a tutor would take the majority or more of a salary coupled with the impossible choice of getting a paycheck at the expense of your child’s academic progression.  This is a no win situation for all.
Many people have been rehired. Let's see what happens.

https://www.cbo.gov/publication/56335
14% second quarter. 15% probably in October.
Many people have been rehired. Let's see what happens.

Unemployment at 11pc.  As people return to work this figure will reduce because some people laid off when there was complete closure will need to be rehired.  However this balances against all the people furloughed and not yet laid off.  So the figure could increase again later in the year.
So balancing the decrease a people go back to work with the opposite, from 11pc it could easily get below 10pc in terms of the bands given before.  But up to 14pc does seems somewhat possible.  Think it’s unlikely to get back to 6pc unless there are loads of restrictions on when someone can apply for unemployment.
It’s going to get worse because the epidemic is getting worse

Ben gave a good pointer in the NYT opinion piece. Furloughs may be going back to work, but structural changes in the economy may result in permanent staff reductions in Sept & October in banks, airlines, entertainment, etc.

There is some chatter that the GOP is interested in extending the unemployment benefit beyond its expiration [1]. Continued lockdowns through fall are likely to further stunt economic activity [2]. Forecasts.com is showing a 10.1% unemployment rate for Aug, last updated July 4th [3]. Based on the GOP interest in giving the country more money, and the continued threat of COVID in a selection of states, I'm going to push my center up. The BLS has admitted that the last two unemployment releases undercounted unemployment due to survey problems related to Covid-19. I personally do not expect much if a second covid-19 wave in the fall. I think we are close to herd immunity, certainly by October. I do expect the economy to be flatline and gradually get worse. Current expanded benefits are set to expire July 31, but I expect this will be extended. This if course incentivises people to stay on unemployment.
Increasing shutdowns in parts of the country that make up a large portion of the labor market. Also, increase in permanent lay-offs is raising the “floor” for a fast recovery
With new outbreaks and closures, expecting the unemployment to go up again
It would appear that reopening will be somewhat muted nationwide with corresponding impact on employment.

Currently the US is in an uncontrolled disaster and states have already been forced to reshut down parts of their economies. It is highly unlikely that the U3 rate gets lower than it was with initial reopenings in June of ~11%. I think that it is likely that it will exceed this, with shutdowns creating the possibility it could even exceed the ~15% registered in April. I think the crowd is being far too conservative on this, and while I think it is possible unemployment doesn’t spiral out of control I think the crowd is failing to account for the fat tail here by having a 0% chance for any rate more than 18%...
My guess is that it will be right on the bubble, going either way the week it's measured.

I am wiggling around like a worm on a hook. Today's numbers said 11.1% for June. Assuming a gentle errosion of the number over the summer and into the fall. If contruction is back that is good, if some retail is back that is good.
If carryout keeps cooks employed that is good. Assume scars remain for years to come as business try to find new footing and job seekers new skills.
Updating to reflect unemployment dropping to 11% for June: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/02/jobs-report-june-2020.html?__source=twitter%7Cmain
unemployment falling at average rate of ~1.8% per month. Expected to taper off after initial drop, but not expecting it to jump up.
+12% to 6-10, -6% to 10-14, -5% to 14-18, -1% to 18-22. Unemployment rate fell to 11.1% in June from 13.3% in May. A larger move than expected.
The new rate is 11.1% Still cautious due to rising COVID numbers and very high weekly UI claims.
Things may be grim, but hopefully they will be stable and changing for the better.

These payroll and unemployment numbers are mysterious. I was under the impression that ADP data are based on fairly simple math: how many more/fewer people did ADP pay in one month vs others. But apparently not given that the adjustment for May was 5.9M people! They got the sign wrong. How could any meaningful data fluctuate by that much? Did they change methodology? https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-economy-jobs/u-s-private-payrolls-miss-expectations-in-june-adp-idUSL1N2E7225
Swapping forecasts, Hattip @jainsa for an informed observation and model to put into practical terms.

In last 10 years, unemployment has never decreased by more than 0.7% over a period of 5 months. We will need to beat it by almost 5 times to get below 10% from current unemployment of 13.3%. That seems too hopeful.
Updated to reflect current COVID increases and states hitting ‘pause’ on reopening.

I was surprised by the rapid, V-shaped recovery but have also been surprised at the new growth in C19 cases: 
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/
Hattip @dlaiocean for doing the math and convincing me to reapportion slightly higher. Also with things not going well on "opening" some businesses may have second thoughts going forward.

The peak unemployment was in April - 24M - unemployment rate of 14.7%.
UE in May was 21M, rate of 13.3%,
Half of the 24M rehired would result in UE rate of 7.5%.
One-third rehired results in 10%.
Two-third rehired results in 5%.
As the US settles there should be a gradual return by October bringing my forecast to between 6 & 10%
Currently over 16%.  With virus cases still increasing, rehiring will be slower than forecast

Considering current unemployment rates somewhere around 13-14%, with many businesses still far from feeling the total effects of economic downturn, I think rates will stay steady, even possibly rise a few points.  It is highly doubtful that it will go down.  Data thus far reveals that the rich are spending less- which in turn powers our current style of economy downward. And if you believe that giving the rich more tax breaks means they have more money to hire more workers, this may be a time that goes against that theory entirely - as people are scared and the stock market is volatile.  So they hold onto more and are less likely to take big risks. Add to that all of the parents who cannot return to work - despite being asked to - because they have no child care or school or camps to take their children to while they work. So then they get fired, replaced, and left out of the work force. Most importantly, businesses are ready to reopen and doing so, but according to multiple surveys, people are not ready to go to most of them as they are not comfortable.  Unless the business can support online customers and Offer curbside pickup while staying cash +, they will too sadly go under.

A few sources are putting it at 8% or more by the end of the year [1,2], but the estimates are putting it at closer to 10%, instead of the high rate we are at now. Dropping my estimate to closer to that range. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-14/jobless-rate-will-remain-elevated-in-2020-says-fed-s-kaplan
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/10/fed-forecasts-economy/

"Federal Reserve leaders predict a slow recovery for the U.S. economy, with unemployment falling to 9.3 percent by the end of this year." https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/10/fed-forecasts-economy/
There's going to be a second big spike in COVID infections because restrictions are being lifted too soon, and this will cause a second downdraft in employment and the economy by summer's end.

While there is no way things will be "back to normal" by October, if kids go back to school, businesses continue to reopen, and cities realize they cannot survive without events like conventions, the unemployment rate should sink fast.  In fact, while still high, weekly unemployment claims have already declined significantly.
I don’t see the unemployment rate changing much from where it is currently. If it does change it will likely not be for the better.

May numbers were about 16 (not the 14 announced by President).  Reopenings will Add jobs.  Fear of virus will reduce them.  Seems like it may hover in current range for awhile, with chances of moving to next higher or lower range. If big second wave hits, it could go above 22%.  With cases climbing seems unlikely it will fall into lowest range.

Most likely scenario: Covid19 not over, but economies open. Some workers will get jobs back. Some will not. Current forecast by White House advisors and even the Fed are too optimistic. They are trying to create confidence in a dangerous economic situation.
Updating to reflect increased likelihood cities lockdown again
More businesses will fail to make a come-back and more of our service based industry will fail.
Are we talking reality or "government blunder" as we saw with the May report?

Tough one as it depends on how employers react to reopening and whether the most hit industries are able to reopen and if people use them. Hotels, holiday places and restaurants are all areas that are nice to haves and last on the list to open.  They are the most likely to sack people and the most precarious types of job and business.  A lot will go out of business thus reducing at least in the short term, the places for people to find work.  So this section of industry is likely to keep unemployment quite high for a while.  Other sectors will start to find a new normal and rejiggle things by October and so will flatten things out a bit from current high levels caused by the sudden change in circumstances.

We will have to change so much infrastructure and cultural mores and folk ways that it’ll take a long time to reach a new status quo. On that journey many jobs will die out and for a whole few people will have work. Unless we eat the rich.

The unemployment rate surged from 3.5 percent in February to 14.7 percent in April. During March and April, more than 20 million nonfarm payroll jobs were lost; those losses were concentrated in industries that rely on a high degree of in-person interactions, such as leisure and hospitality, retail trade, and education and health services.  The leisure and hospitality sector was hit particularly hard, losing 8 million of its 17 million jobs in March and April.  black and Hispanic people constitute a disproportionate share of workers in certain industries in which many jobs involve elevated risks of exposure to COVID-19. Also, a sharp decline in investment in the second quarter.
In the week ending May 8, the number of active rigs drilling for oil and gas in the United States was 54% below its average in the fourth quarter of 2019.
The architectural billings index fell at a record pace in March.
Construction employment decreased by nearly 13 percent in April.
Sales of cars and light trucks, about half of which are made to businesses and constitute a significant portion of investment in equipment, fell by 49 percent in April from their average in the fourth quarter of 2019.
Mortgage purchase applications, a measure of the demand for new and existing homes, were 30 percent lower in April than they were a year earlier. In addition, many local economies that rely heavily on the tourism and hospitality industries have sustained great employment losses.

Overall, I'm pessimistic. At this time, the end of May, there are around 20-25% of the workforce claiming unemployment. Looking at other historical depressions, I can see very little precedent (or plausible mechanism) for a fast recovery to pre-crisis levels, and so I'm putting the first band as extremely unlikely, at 1%. Likewise, I think major govt. job programs or other interventions are unlikely, which are the main way I can see that unemployment would get down below 10% that rapidly, so I put a low probability on that band. Overall, I believe that a) the true unemployment rate is currently +20% (will see when this month's report is released) and b) that it is likely to stay up around this level, though with fluctuations, for the coming months. In the even that future waves of COVID are mild, and second-order consequences are limited, we might see mild recovery into the 14-18% band. If the future waves are more severe, possibly to the point of triggering additional lockdowns, then unemployment will remain higher, and even the risk of them will serve to dampen economic recovery and growth. Second-order consequences are harder to predict, but I'm concerned about additional economic shocks and unrest keeping unemployment high, or even worsening things into the top band.  Will update when May unemployment figures released.

April will almost certainly go down as the worst month ever for American workers. The jobs report, out Friday, will likely reveal the highest U.S. unemployment rate on record at 15% to 20%, but even that figure will probably understate the scale of joblessness across the nation. The unemployment rate in the United States will peak at 25%, rivaling the worst period of the Great Depression, Goldman Sachs warned on Wednesday. No matter where the unemployment peaks, economists have cautioned that it will take years, perhaps even more than a decade, to get the jobless rate back near pre-crisis levels. Goldman Sachs expects the unemployment rate to stand around 10% at the end of 2020. For context, that matches the worst levels of the Great Recession. And even by the end of 2021, Goldman Sachs sees unemployment above 8%.

I have a better understanding now of how unemployment is measured and understand that it leads to lower official numbers than what I was thinking for the same level of true underlying unemployment.  On the other hand, conditions have worsened since my last estimate.  Currently unemployment is ~14.7%. I assume there are going to be significant factors pushing it around:  -- Strong political / stimulus efforts to push it down. -5%
-- Continued rollforward of existing losses already backed in: +7%
-- short-term unemployed becoming long-term unemployed: +5%
-- semi-employed becoming unemployed: +5%
-- unemployed people giving up on looking for work: -5% For me this factor is the biggest wildcard.  So I'm still expecting this to go up another 5+% and I'm not expecting for it to get dramatically better by October.

1% U3 rate has just been announced - 14.7%. It's within my first forecasts estimation but on the very high side.  The rate may increase again as suspected, but over the next 5 months it will probably start to decrease due to the US economy opening back up. However, I suspect this decrease will be lower than expected with no 'bounce back'. This is because a large number of businesses will not have the ability to start employing again and their confidence will be low. Also, a second wave becomes more likely with the easing of restrictions. In my previous forecast, I suspected that there would be a longer lockdown in the US compared to what is happening. This means people will still be searching for work throughout the crisis, contributing to the U3 measurement continually for the next 6 months.  Next month's rate could increase to 15%-18% because there is a lag to the U3 measurement. (only included up until the 12th of last month). I think next month's rate will be the peak, followed and a slow but increasing decline until October.  I think the true economic damage will take longer than October to surface, but low confidence should prevent the expected 'bounce back'.

From April 2020 to March 2020, the reported unemployment rate rose from 3.5% to 4.5%. This trend will most likely continue as businesses remain limited in capacity and closed during shelter-in-place protocols. As economic growth declines, the Fed has lowered its target ratio to near 0%, mirror the actions taken to avoid economic recession in 2008. Looking at the unemployment rates that occurred during the 2008 recession, unemployment rose, capping off at 10% in 2010 and slowly returning the natural rate. Comparing this trend to the predicted trend of U.S. civilian unemployment rates for 2020, it is likely that by October 2020, the U3 rate will be above 6% but not higher than 14%.

I am not an employment/unemployment expert.  Should I even try to forecast this question?  I have decided to do so.  The pandemic is a once-in-a-lifetime event.  I ought to know something about its effect on the economy. Background first:
One would think that unemployment rate is simply the number of unemployed divided by the number of employed people.  Not so as far as the US government statistics are concerned.  Terms like “active job seekers”, “seasonally adjusted numbers”, “discouraged job seekers”, “part-timers”, “under-employed” and “temporarily unemployed” float around.  U3 unemployment rate (in this forecast) specifically counts only the active job seekers.
This leads to an important question.  Will all of the massive increase of unemployed people due to the shutdown of the economy be counted as active job seekers, and therefore included in the U3 (even though there are few jobs available to be seeked)?  Current situation:
There is no way I can account for all (or even the most) of the nuances involved in coming up with the U3 rate as defined by the government.  I will do my best to estimate the unemployment rate as I see fit.

Two assumptions are used here.  First is that I count all the unemployed people due to the economic shutdown and make no determination of whether they are active job seekers or not.  Second is that I use 160M as the baseline employment number (E0) before the slowdown [1].  I will subtract the unemployment (UE) from E in calculating the unemployment rate.  That is UER = UE/(E0-UE). Lets do a consistency check first.  The Bureau of Labor Statistics [2] reports 7.1M unemployed people in March 2020.  Therefore 7.1/(160-7.1) = 4.6%.  This is similar to the 4.4% reported [2].  (If you just divide 7.1 by 160, you actually get 4.4%, but it is important to subtract out the UE in the denominator when the UE is a significant fraction of E – see next paragraph). Various reports show that the total UE is 22M on the week of 11 April [3].  Therefore the current unemployment rate is 22/(160-22) = 16%.  (If you don’t subtract 22 from the denominator, it would be 14%).  Note that this rate is much higher than some of the forecast rates [4], even though the 16% does not include the expected increases in the second half of April. Looking into the future: About 95% of the US population is under some forms of lockdown. Only five states (North and South Dakota, Nebraska, Arkansas and Iowa) have no stay-at-home orders at all, but they constitute to a small percentage of the US population.  Therefore the weekly INCREASE in unemployment should be tapering off soon.  This view is consistent with the data – newly unemployed are 6.9M, 6.6M and 5.2M for the last 3 weeks (oldest first) [3].   If you take a linear trend, the total unemployed will peak at ~30M in several weeks, making the peak unemployment rate to be 30/(160-30) = 23%.  This is my starting point of the unemployment rate for the economic recovery. For the forecast question, we need to deal with 3 questions first.
1.	When will the economy start to open up?
2.	How fast will the economy recover after opening up? 
3.	How many of the 30M unemployed will be hired again? The virus outbreak is definitely slowing down.  Realistically the US will open up its economy before covid-19 is completely "wiped out", if that is possible.  Some risks will be taken, and I think the government people know that.  (The decision is likened to the famous economist's example of allowable car speed limits.  If you want no car deaths, set a speed limit of 5 mph, but it reduces significantly the economic activities.  By setting it at 55 mph, you are allowing an acceptable amount of car deaths, but at the same time allowing the economy to function).   I expect the gradual opening up in the June-July time frame. While it took 3 years for the US to recover from the 2008 Great Recession, I expect it will be faster this time.  The large companies will have to deal with supply chain issues, but they will be helped by the federal government (too big to fail!).  Their recovery could be relatively fast.  The small business, which constitutes to 50% of the US economy, will have a hard time restarting.  The federal funds designated to help small businesses is dried up already [6].  Their recovery could be much slower.  Many of them could fail. To bracket my forecasts:
If one-third of the 30M unemployed get rehired, UE rate would be 14%.
If half of the 30M unemployed get rehired, UE rate would be 10%.
If two-third of the 30M unemployed get rehired (a very optimistic scenario), UE rate would be 7%. Unfortunately these rates lie on the boundaries of the forecast baskets, which makes it harder to put numbers in them. [1]  https://www.statista.com/statistics/269959/employment-in-the-united-states/
[2]  https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf
[3]  https://www.vox.com/2020/4/16/21223049/unemployment-filings-high-great-depression
[4] https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/unemployment-rate
[5]  https://www.businessinsider.com/us-map-stay-at-home-orders-lockdowns-2020-3
[6]  https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/15/us/politics/coronavirus-small-business-program.html

I'm finally getting a bit more organized about my thinking. Currently unemployment is 4%. I assume it's going to be ~14% higher in October, so about 18%. However I'm adding a big error bar of 8% - 25% because there are a lot of unknowns.  First, I am not working from the mindset that the economy is going to come roaring back in a V-shaped recovery. I think inertia will keep this down for a while. 
1) leisure and restaurants are going to be hit hard for a long time. That's like 10-15% of the workforce 
2) oil is going to be hurting for a long time
3) there is a global recession so overseas demand won't fix the problem and the time lag is longer than 6 months
4) The problems above will cause flow-through problems to the rest of the economy over a period of months Big picture: currently there are 22M more people unemployed than a month ago and losses are continuing. Let's say that job losses have peaked and in a month that number grows to "just" 35M. That's over 20% of all of the workers in the US and it comes on top of the 4M who were already unemployed.  Getting a significant fraction of 35M people into new jobs is going to be tough: 
1) ongoing domestic and global recession
2) some sectors are gone (leisure) and others are up (home delivery, streaming) so most people will need substantial re-purposing I'm not sure how to factor in government aid. Currently it appears that generous unemployment will encourage people to not seek jobs. Plus there aren't nearly enough jobs available. If there are massive employment projects between now and October, then that could help. It will be easiest for people who already work in areas like construction, but that's a drop in the bucket. Infrastructure projects sound good, but can we really employ 20-40M people mostly from hospitality building dams, power lines, roads and whatever? It seems like a stretch. Maybe we'll try to hire 20M people into the military or some new part of the federal government ... but to do what?  First, I see Leisure and hospitality (10% of all jobs) to be way down in fall. Until there's a cure, who's going to go on vacation, eat in restaurants, etc? Not me. -50% of pre-COVID levels could turn out to be optimistic. Maybe -75%. Also retail (10%) will be down, say 25%.  The above will cause flow-through disruption to other areas: financial services, manufacturing, mining, professional services, wholesale that are collectively ~50% of the workforce. I assume they will be down by something like 15%. I see Federal, State and Local employment (14%) to pretty steady or up.

"The consensus of 57 economists surveyed this month by The Wall Street Journal is that 14.4 million jobs will be lost in the coming months, and the unemployment rate will rise to a record 13% in June" https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-second-round-of-coronavirus-layoffs-has-begun-no-one-is-safe-11586872387?mod=trending_now_1 I'm very uncertain as to whether the unemployment rate for October will be better or worse than the 13% that is forecast for June. On the one hand, there is time for the recession to deepen between June and October - especially if lockdowns have to be re-instated. On the other hand, the fall might be the start of a rebound. It'll all mostly depend on the extent to which COVID-19 mitigation efforts are successful through the summer. Tentatively, I will assume that these two possibilities cancel out and that the unemployment rate in October will hold steady at the ~13% figure that is currently forecast for June.
Perhaps the worst will be over by Sept and reopening happens then with people returning to work.

Very difficult to predict. Typically, a GDP impact of the like we will see over the coming months would result in a devastatingly high (>25%) unemployment rate. There's also a decent chance that the US lockdown extends longer than current predictions suggest and lasts well into Q3 given US deaths show little sign of slowing down. However, balanced against that is the impact of furloughing on workers who will technically not count as unemployed as a result. There may therefore be a very number of inactive Americans who don't count in the BSL numbers. With these factors in mind, I judge that the most likely outcome is between 10 and 18% (precise prediction probably around 15%).

I'll definitely be coming back to update this, primarily unsure because of the comments made by @Okanaganopolis and @A356 about what metric will actually be used...on top of it depending SO heavily on where things go with COVID, how long stay-at-home continues, testing, etc. and how long it takes for confidence to begin coming back to the extent that employers even consider adding.
initial bet, this seems very far away right now.

Current unemployment rate is estimated to be about 13%. GS forecasted 15% in 3rd quarter. Other forecasts have been as high as 30%. How bad it gets and how quickly it recovers depends on the battle against COVID. 
We're probably looking at multiple waves of covid19 over the year, however (a) the worst of the first wave should be over in June and there is some potential for new treatments in this timeframe that could lessen the impact. Given that it's an election year, the WH will throw money at the economy until it runs out of money to throw. This degree to which that works will depend on whether it's safe for people to return to work. Push people back too hard and too fast, and we worsen the epidemic.

Flying blind, we know the number who have filed for benefits, about 16M in last few weeks, that is 10% of the working population.  Add that to the 4% already UE and you get 14% as a simple number. More to follow as businesses throw in the towel and try to preserve cash. How soon will restarants, barber shops, auto dealers and retail get back to work.

Significant risk of another wave of virus in the fall, so my best guess is between 10 & 20% unemployment through the end of the year (but not sure where in that range). Very small chance of less than 10%, even if # of cases falls in summer, because it will take time for employers to re-hire and continued uncertainty. Significant chance that unemployment is over 20% if the pandemic continues on current path.

This isn't a case where historical numbers help us. We've never had a recessions where part of the actual goal was to have people stop working. Now, weekly unemployment has been over 5 million per week though it flattened this week vs. last week.  This was already like 7x the highest weekly UE we ever saw in the Great Recession. Even at some steady state assumption of 2 million per week, we'd end up with 33% unemployment by end of October (Labor force is ~160 million people and we could end up with 50 million or more unemployed people by October). Peak unemployment in the Great Recession was 10% and thus far, this looks 3-6x worse than anything we saw then. Now, normally the big wild card here would be the size of a stimulus which could cap this.  Problems are, a) we can't enact stimulus right now because we need people at home, not working. So this isn't the kind of thing Stimulus can sort out; b) there is good reason to believe, if a stimulus later comes out, it will be poorly targeted (i.e. tax cuts don't help people who have already lost a job since they aren't paying tax anyway).

there's a great set of questions asked by newbie @A356 i read. Many are betting quite high. But the question begs: "what constitutes" the actual STATISTIC that comes out at the end? I'm feeling like the question's about as squishy as "How many cases  of Covid? vs what metric"   This question's bet depends on WHO YOU TEST AND HOW OFTEN. vs. the U3 metric. I'm considering lowering further once i hear from some of the salacious "quants" out there looking into this. :-)
Current effective rate is 14.7, I don't see any scenario that it goes lower by October.

As of April 9th, consensus @ 13% unemployment rate. Great Depression had a peak of 25%. Expect unemployment rate to fall gradually when lock-down ends this summer but some social distancing measures to remain in place, forcing businesses where people are normally in close quarters to operate at a lower capacity. Some businesses will not survive. Travel and tourism industry jobs will also be muted.

Very difficult question! I suspect many forecasters will predict how high the peak will be instead of when the peak will be. I’ve broken it down into 3 questions: 1.	What will the U3 unemployment rate be at its peak?
2.	When will this peak happen/what will the gradient look like either side of the peak?
3.	According to this curve, what will the rate in October be? 1. The mean average peak of the last 10 spikes in the U3 unemployment rate (U3UR) = 7.86%. The highest = 10.8% (1982) and the lowest = 6.1% (1954/1971). Historically, there is a relationship between the size of the GDP decrease and the magnitude of the spike. However, this is not always the case e.g. 1949 post-war recession. Using past examples may be misleading for this question because the COVID-19 crisis will have a unique effect on the US economy. That being said, they cannot be dismissed as useless. Although there is a record number of unemployment insurance claims, this will not directly correlate with the U3UR in terms of timing or numbers. This is because a vast majority of those people will be classed as marginally attached and for a large proportion of this crisis may not be looking for work as there won’t be any. Perhaps the U3UR will start to increase more substantially as the economy starts to roll again and more jobs are available.
Size of the labor force in Dec 2019 = 164.6 million Already U3 unemployed in Dec 2019 = 5.761 million (3.5%) Very vulnerable jobs = 93.68 million (leisure & hospitality/education & health/professional & business services/retail/construction/transport) 30% of these jobs could be lost in the short term (very unsure about this number –complete guesstimate) 30% of 93.68 million = 28.104 million Non ‘vulnerable jobs’ at risk = 2.5 million (another complete guestimate) Total = 30.604 million How many out of these will be searching for a job during the COVID-19 peak? No idea! Let’s say between 5 million and 20 million (+ 5.761 already U3 unemployed) = between 10.761 million and 25.761 million (between 6.54% and 15.65% U3UR) 2. The average time lag between initial U3UR rise and the peak of last 10 spikes = 17.8 months Important to say that these were caused by recessions. There probably will be a recession on the back of this crisis and I believe there will be 2 spikes in the next 2 years. One caused by COVID-19 and a second by a recession. The rapidly increasing debt levels are very worrying for the near future. Historically, does a larger peak mean a steeper gradient? No. 3. I think there will be a substantial rise in the next 2 months. After 2 months the impact of the virus should be diminishing (estimating this from curves of other countries and the trajectory of the curves), businesses will cautiously begin to hire, giving people more incentive to start looking for jobs. I believe this will cause the first peak in around 4-5 months at around 13%. I believe it will decrease quite sharply over the next few months but in October, I estimate it will be around 10%. Criticism is very welcome, I’m extremely unsure about this one!

This one's tough because it depends so much on the course of the virus. It's possible we will continue to have bouts of it that keep unemployment very high. I'm not sure the world economy would put up with that for 6 more months, though, so I'm expecting a lot of unemployment, but not at astronomical levels.
COVID-19 impact will be worse than the Financial Crisis (U3 peaked at 10% in October 2009)

Looking at the forecasts, it seems like <6% is completely out of the question. I've even seen some people say it is already over 10%. It is hard to figure out how much of this we can trust, and how much of this is sensationalism. What we can say with certainty is: since the outbreak has started, 10 million people have filed unemployment claims. it looks like the number of claims is greater during the 2008 recession by an order of magnitude. The question is whether this rate is going to continue or whether it's going to slow down considerably. The unemployment rate in the 2008 recession went below 10%, and it seems like it worse than that. There is a lot of uncertainty at this time. It seems more like a guessing game. There is a lot of risk for really low unemployment rates though. Comparing my forecast to the crowd forecast, it looks like I might be falling victim reading sensationalized news articles. I made a few adjustments, but I'm going to take the risk and go with this.
Economic response is pretty good. Social distancing will relax even if the pandemic continues.

Currently we are at about 13% unemployment from COVID-19 (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/upshot/coronavirus-jobless-rate-great-depression.html).  Understanding that unemployment during the Great Depression peaked at nearly 25% (https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-coronavirus-labor-market-unemployment-rapid-recovery-recession-experts-2020-4)  it is hard to believe that anything close to that is possible by October.  Even 18% seems to be a stretch. The valleys shown in the NYTimes article referenced are typically not below 6% for very long either, making that seem relatively unrealistic as well. The remaining guess is a more optimistic view of our society getting a better handle on COVID-19 by summer and many (unfortunately not all) people returning to work.
guessing unemployment with reach its max before october then decline

Outside view:
Current 4.4% - Ten year average 7.2%. 
Regression to the mean. 5.8 %  https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/unemployment-rate I have done a meta analysis average using a wide range experts  (https://www.forbes.com/sites/sergeiklebnikov/2020/03/31/how-bad-will-unemployment-get-heres-what-the-experts-predict/#60feeed84f16) - including the regressive mean value above which has turned out at 14.33% I cant see it hitting the highs of 22%, as @bobrown rightly points out. In the great depression unemployment peaked at 25%, since then we have had an increase of working from home opportunities and global working.

It's an election year and DC is going to do all it can to get people back to work quickly, but there are significant headwinds due to the virus. Also, in the autumn, we may see a resurgence, but by that time, we may have a better work-around to have people working.

I "feel" like a lot of things will have changed forever by end of October.  Some permanent "new paradigms" may be in place by then.  I.E., for starters, will as many commute to work as they used to? Why would they? Will "commuter services" retreat? (lunch places, cafe's, etc... less gas, oil changes, etc..., ) Corporate Travel will take some permanent capacity adjustments. So Hotel/Air Travel stuff will be reduced. Staycations and close-tourism places will thrive, but not this year. Absent a vaccine by Oct (too soon) the herd will still be sensitive to contagion, so many "crowd" events will remain off the list, I suspect. Bars, NightClubs, in tight quarters will have a hard time getting back to normal. The "consumer" mentality will have softened too.  So what will all the unemployed do for a living? I'm looking more to the thirties and not the 2000's for "base-rate"  Please tear into this with your critiques. and wash your hands :-)

There is nothing in the news today to give me any confidence that Coronavirus will be under control by then, I believe that the trend will be down, but until there is a effective vaccine we will not be fighting a winning battle.

The effect of this crisis ill probably be worse than 2008 financial crisis (10%).
The CBO is predicting unemployment will be 9% in Q4 2021, so this is likely to last a while. And there is more going on with the economy than the virus. It won't be below 10% in October.

This questions concerns October 2020, which is in the 4th quarter of the year. The USA economy is expected to bounce back violently in the 3rd quarter, any peaks in the unemployment rate would occur in the 2nd quarter, and these would be 'artificial' in nature. For example the million's of barbers, stylists, psychiatrists, bartenders and the like would are out of work because of gov't enforced social distancing rules aren't gone forever. They will bounce back quickly once the economy is reopened. 
But demands in the housing and heavy industry field may still be suppressed by low demands so the unemployment rates aren't immediately going to fall back under 10% so quickly. Lot's of bankruptcies will take place, and consolidation between rivals (or takeover's) to help compete in this period of uncertainty will cost the jobs of numerous employees.

I think the pandemic will peak no earlier than July 20, 2020.  After the peak the rate of new cases and deaths will only gradually come down.   I don't foresee many state, or city governments (the Trump Administration is worse than useless) loosening up travel and work restrictions while thousands of citizens are continuing to be infected, albeit at a lower rate than between April 1 and July 31, 2020.
